EPA RMP Executive Summary

Chemical Research & Licensing uses a Health Safety and Environmental Management System to define and mange risks at our facility.

Chemical Research & Licensing is committed to the protection of the Occupational Health and Safety of the people in our workplace, the public and the Environment.  We believe that all occupational illnesses, injuries and environmental incidents are preventable, and that their occurrence is unacceptable.  Chemical Research & Licensing's objective is to continuously improve its Health, Safety and Environmental performance and in doing so become recognized as a leader in our industry.  Chemical Research & Licensing will comply with the intent as well as the letter of all applicable Health, Safety and Environmental Laws where we operate, and where we believes those laws and regulations are inadequate, we will establish appropriate, and more stringent internal standards.

In accordance with policy, Chemical Research & Licensing will:

* Operate its facilities in compliance will all applicable federal, state and local regulations.
* Consider Health, Safety and Environmental implications during product development, testing, processing and storage.
* Devote sufficient resources to be viewed as an industry leader in the area of Health, Safety and Environmental performance.

Risk Management (i. e. identifying and managing hazards and potentially adverse effects of activities on people, the environment, assets or reputation) is a vital part of HSE management and is the heart of any HSE MS.  It consists of four basic steps:
* Identification
* Assessment
* Provision of Controls
* Recovery Preparedness

The assessment of risks and hazards should include consideration of the full life cycle of an activity from beginning to end.  All of these steps should be documented.

Chemical Research & Licensing shall:
* Identify major HSE hazards and potentially adverse effects and assess the related risks which could arise from the Co

mpany's existing, or proposed new, activities (including acquisitions, divestment, abandonment or merger) and which could potentially impact:
* Health and safety of employees, contractors and the public.
* The environment including soil and groundwater contamination.
* The company's reputation, liability or profitability.
* Asset damage.
* Use risk assessment methodologies, including scenarios and consequence/probability ratings (Risk Assessment Matrix), which are appropriate for the hazard, effect and associated risk being considered.
* Apply as a function of the risk level, appropriate controls to prevent, or reduce likelihood of, occurrence and applies appropriate recovery measures to reduce the possible effects of the HSE risks.
* Assure that measures for risk control and recovery are adequate and clearly linked with related tasks/activities (competence/responsibility) that are assigned to specific individuals in the organization.
* Manage changes to facilities, processes, operations and other activities to assure that hazards, effects and risks are reassessed and that plans for HSE event prevention, control and recovery are updated accordingly.
* Apply Product Stewardship as part of a HSE Management process that manages hazards and effects during all phases of the life cycle of our products.

Chemical Research & Licensing is a piloting and research facility relating to the petro-chemical industry.  The product we create is technology.  This technology is related to refining processes that use catalysts to speed up production using less equipment.  Our SIC Code is 8731 (NAICS Code is 54171). 

Emergency Response Systems:
* Mobile fire protection equipment consists portable 20 pound and wheeled 50 pound mobile fire extinguishers
* Water fog can be used to minimize the effect of releases by knocking down vapors and cool tanks
* Alarm systems will notify employees and neighboring facility of an emergency
* Trained emergency responders are able to isolate the point

of release
* Communication link to off-site responders
* Information can be posted on the CAER line system to notify the public and neighboring facilities of the type of emergency and what action is to be taken, i.e., Shelter-in-Place.

Shelter-In-Place:
* Upon notification, Go inside immediately
* Shut all doors and windows
* Turn off AC/heaters to stop outside air from getting inside
* Turn on the radio and listen for instructions
* Stay off the phone

Chemical Research & Licensing has had no reportable releases of toxic or flammable substances in the past five years that have impacted the community or the environment.

Emergency Response Program:

It is the policy of Chemical Research & Licensing (CR&L) to establish and maintain an effective state of emergency preparedness with respect to managing emergencies on the operating site.  It is the responsibility of all CR&L employees to be familiar with their roles and responsibilities identified in the plan and the plan in general.   This shall be done through provision and availability of:

* Effective emergency response plans that encompass necessary responses and that interface adequately with Community emergency response.
* Adequately trained employees.
* Regular emergency drills.

The purpose of the Emergency Response Manual is to provide direction and assistance to effectively manage emergencies.

The objectives of this manual are:

* define organization, roles and responsibilities for designated personnel during emergencies
* outline emergency response actions
* provide check lists to assist with emergency management effectiveness

The facility emergency alarm system consists of paging horns, fire alarms, and high and low gas detection alarms.  All alarms are audible and are either automatically activated or can be manually activated.  To manually activate the alarms you must depress the red Alarm Activation button for two seconds on the fire alarm panel.  An all clear announcement will be made once any da

nger has passed.

The first priority following any incident must be the health and safety of all persons involved. The response will depend on the incident and the resources readily available, and may include the administration of first aid, fire suppression, evacuation, shutting off equipment and/or notifying the ambulance police or fire departments.  Once the situation is secured, additional assistance may be sought as required and notification procedures must be initiated.

As part of the RMP management process, continual training is provided to company employees directly affected by the RMP rule.  The installation of permanent hard piping will be done in 2002 negating the use of flexible process lines currently in use with some RMP chemicals.  Best management and industrial practices will continue to drive safety for handling all chemicals at CR&L.

We have three (3) EPA RMP listed chemicals on site: 1,3-Butadiene, 1-Butene, and Isobutane.  These chemicals are stored in LPG rated tanks and tankers in quantities not greater than 40,000 pounds.  Our worst-case release scenario is a vapor cloud explosion which has an off-site 1 pound over pressure impact of up to .3 miles or 1746 feet from the center of the event.  Calculations for making this determination are taken from EPA's RMP Comp. software.

Worst Case Scenario:
* Vapor cloud explosion
* Instantaneous failure of inner and outer tank walls simultaneously
* Failure of all active safety systems
* Worst-case weather conditions: stable, low wind speed
* Total release- entire vessel contents of 40,000 in 10 minutes
* Area impacted .3 miles (1,746 feet)

Alternative Release Scenario:
* Vapor Cloud Explosion
* Failure of a 2 loading hose
* Active and passive safety systems working
* Emergency shutdown system isolates release
* Most common weather conditions
* Release rate 31 pounds per minute
* Total release time 15 minutes
* Area impacted .10 miles (582 feet)

Accident Prevention Measures:
* Storage vessels are high-pressure construction, pressure relieves to flare
* High flow shutoff valve on LPG trailer
* Emergency equipment shutdown procedures
* Remote valves to isolate and limit release
* Water fog for releases
* Regulatory guidelines for safe operation (OSHA Process safety and EPA RMP)
* Risk management
* Mechanical

integrity
* Employee training
* Process hazard analysis
* Policies and procedures for safe operation of equipment

* Communication link to off-site responders
